website_summaries.verdict: If you need a hex screwdriver for minor to mid-level tasks, this tool will suit your needs – but it's not built to stand up to contractor-level jobs.
pros: A revamped hex model that is fairly compact and lightweight
Battery charges quickly and lasts a long time
cons: The RPMs aren't suited for extremely heavy duty jobs
You have to purchase the battery separately

customer_reviews.title: Replacement for one dropped onto concrete
customer_reviews.text: I bought this product to replace one of the same model number that broke in a fall from a ladder onto concrete. This is an updated design, the most noticeable difference is that the size changed a little. The distance from the chuck to the back of the motor portion is around 3/8-1/2" shorter, the handle is portion longer by about the same amount. The older version also didn't have a belt hook, I'm not sure if I'll be using it. I have a number of Milwaukee M12 tools. They can do maybe 80-90% of the jobs that their M18 cousins can do but with less weight and resulting fatigue.
customer_reviews.author: GaryW

customer_reviews.title: Tried and true, an excellent buy...
customer_reviews.text: This is my favorite cordless screwdriver on the market today. There are ones with more powerful brushless motors that are made for heavier duty jobs and there are ones with more precision built into them, but this one falls right in between and offers a great balance for light to medium duty jobs. It's, by far, my most used cordless screwdriver in my arsenal. It's also been around for a little while and is still being sold. Tried and true, this is an excellent buy.
customer_reviews.author: Rich Niewiroski Jr.

customer_reviews.title: Alway's the best!
customer_reviews.text: I'm a professional appliance service tech and used the blue brand X tools for years. Then I bought a Milwaukee ratchet, I was hooked! These are the best electric tool I've ever used and in the past 39 years I've used a few. Buy them & use them, you won't be sorry!

customer_reviews.title: Switching to Milwaukee
customer_reviews.text: I have a full array of Rigid products with 18 volt batteries. I have been picking up the 12 volt Milwaukee tools for the last few months just because of the compact size and quality. Even though the parent company of Rigid, Milwaukee and Ryobi as well as some others is one and the same, it appears that they are made in different factories and quality. While Rigid has the best service plan of any tool, the Milwaukee brand is lighter and seems better built.

customer_reviews.title: Great updated driver.

customer_reviews.title: Glad I grabbed this instead of the 2406-20 or the 2402-20

I struggled with purchasing this, the two speed 2406-20, or the fuel 2402-20 screwdriver to complement the rest of my tools. Since I was only looking for a general purpose screwdriver, the two speed version and the fuel version seem somewhat unnecessary. Glad I went with this tool, especially for the sub $43 price I paid.

customer_reviews.title: Awesome driver!
customer_reviews.text: The best screwdriver I've used ever. It's heavier than the Ryobi I replaced, but honestly I do not care. I did try to loosen a hex-screw but it was way too overtighten. The driver did shutdown, but at least I worked again right away. I suspect that it will not remove certain bolts or screws that are either overtighten or lock-tight. Other than that this performs phenomenally with majority of projects that require you to either remove screws or bolts and bolt-on mounts, plywood, boards, brackets, etc. Milwaukee is the best power tool manufacturer bar none!
